name: Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM)
summary: An ancient holistic medical system from China that integrates herbal medicine, acupuncture, dietary therapy, Qigong, and massage to restore balance of Qi and promote health.
description: Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) is a holistic medical system developed over thousands of years in China, rooted in the concepts of Yin-Yang balance, Qi (vital energy), and the Five Elements. It emphasizes individualized diagnosis and treatment to restore harmony within the body and between the individual and environment. Core TCM modalities include herbal medicine, acupuncture, dietary therapy, Tuina (therapeutic massage), and Qigong/Tai Chi practices. TCM is widely used for a variety of conditions including chronic pain, digestive disorders, women’s health, stress, and preventive wellness. While many of its theories are not directly translatable into biomedical frameworks, growing research supports certain TCM interventions, particularly acupuncture and herbal formulations, in integrative care contexts.

metadata.invasiveness_level: Variable – non-invasive (Qigong, diet) to minimally invasive (acupuncture)
setting: Hospitals (in China and some global contexts)
treatment_duration: Acute conditions: several sessions over 2–4 weeks
Chronic conditions: ongoing or seasonal care
metadata.training_required: Licensed TCM practitioner (L.Ac., DOM, or equivalent certification); extensive training in diagnostics, herbalism, and acupuncture
metadata.regulatory_status: Widely regulated in Asia; varies globally—licensed in some Western jurisdictions, complementary status in others

conditions_treated: Irritable bowel syndrome and functional dyspepsia
contraindications: Absolute: none universal; specific to modality (e.g., acupuncture over infection, toxic herbs)
Relative: pregnancy (avoid certain herbs and acupuncture points), bleeding disorders (for acupuncture)
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe with trained practitioners; risks include herb-drug interactions, acupuncture complications (rare), and misdiagnosis if used as sole therapy.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate – strong evidence for acupuncture and select herbal remedies; variable evidence across modalities.

sections.text: TCM is based on the regulation of Qi, Yin-Yang balance, and harmonization of the Five Elements. Acupuncture is thought to stimulate meridians, influencing neurohormonal and autonomic pathways. Herbal medicine provides bioactive compounds with pharmacological effects. Tuina and Qigong improve circulation, flexibility, and energy flow. Biomedical perspectives suggest effects on neuroendocrine modulation, immune function, and stress pathways.

sections.preparation: Detailed TCM diagnostic evaluation (pulse, tongue, history, pattern differentiation).
procedure: Individualized treatment plan developed based on syndrome differentiation.
Modalities applied (e.g., acupuncture, herbal formulas, Tuina).
Lifestyle, diet, and exercise recommendations (Qigong, Tai Chi).
Regular follow-ups to adjust treatment based on response.
sections.frequency: 1–2 times weekly for acute or moderate conditions; ongoing for chronic or preventive care.
sections.duration: 30–90 minutes per session depending on modality.
sections.total_treatment_time: Varies; weeks to months for chronic conditions, seasonal for wellness.

items: Dietary therapy based on TCM principles

immediate: Relaxation, improved circulation, sense of balance
short_term: Symptom reduction, stress relief, improved digestion
long_term: Better disease management, enhanced resilience, improved quality of life

absolute: Use of toxic herbs without supervision
special_considerations: Ensure quality control in herbal products.
Integrate with conventional care for chronic illness.

ideal_candidates: Patients with chronic pain or digestive complaints
Those interested in preventive and holistic wellness
screening_required: Check for contraindications in herbs and acupuncture

lifestyle_recommendations: Balanced diet consistent with TCM principles
Daily exercise such as Tai Chi or Qigong

sections.total_treatment_cost: Varies widely; ongoing costs for chronic or preventive care
sections.insurance_coverage: Partial coverage common for acupuncture; less consistent for herbal medicine

items: TCM emphasizes individualized treatment based on syndrome differentiation.
Strong evidence exists for acupuncture in chronic pain and nausea.
Herbal medicine requires caution due to interactions and quality control.
TCM is widely integrated in China’s hospitals and increasingly in global integrative medicine.
